body: Fun times on the bleeding edge

Sometimes it's no `fun` - even with jdk-9: 
```
:junit-jupiter-api:compileKotline: java.rmi.NoSuchObjectException: no such object in table
	at java.rmi/sun.rmi.transport.StreamRemoteCall.exceptionReceivedFromServer(StreamRemoteCall.java:283)
	at java.rmi/sun.rmi.transport.StreamRemoteCall.executeCall(StreamRemoteCall.java:260)
	at java.rmi/sun.rmi.server.UnicastRef.invoke(UnicastRef.java:161)
	at java.rmi/java.rmi.server.RemoteObjectInvocationHandler.invokeRemoteMethod(RemoteObjectInvocationHandler.java:209)
	at java.rmi/java.rmi.server.RemoteObjectInvocationHandler.invoke(RemoteObjectInvocationHandler.java:161)
	at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy93.clearJarCache(Unknown Source)
	at org.jetbrains.kotlin.compilerRunner.GradleCompilerRunner.compileWithDaemon(GradleKotlinCompilerRunner.kt:215)
```
Restarting the build "solves" this and other issues... most of the times.

Disabled the Kotlin Compiler Daemon ... now running into an ignorable(?) warning

`"w: The '-d' option with a directory destination is ignored because '-Xbuild-file' is specified"`

See https://travis-ci.org/junit-team/junit5/jobs/304295302#L751
I'm getting this warning from time to time after the Kotlin daemon crashed.

_"We use ASM 6.0_ALPHA in the Kotlin compiler. This problem is going to be fixed by using ASM 6.0 instead."_

https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-21303#comment=27-2566164

Unfortunately this happens to me quite regularly lately but for jdk-8
```
:junit-jupiter-api:compileKotline: java.rmi.NoSuchObjectException: no such object in table
...
```

About to disable Kotlin support on Java 10 for the time being. Seeing 99% of our build run on Java 10 is more important than waiting for Kotlin to update their shadowed ASM dependency. I guess by March 2018, when Java 10 is released, the following commit https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/commit/f592863a00bf037070456866c543fa44e7000c0c may be reverted for good.

issue.title: KT-21303: Kotlin isn't supported on jdk-10+ea-31

repository.name: kotlin-dsl-samples
repository.description: Samples builds using the Gradle Kotlin DSL

issue.body:
I haven't actually tried this myself but this is according to the Junit 5 team.

Just something I thought I should make everyone aware of. I know this issue isn't directly related to this project.

https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-21303

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1169

body:
Java 10 support is expected to arrive with Kotlin **1.2.30**.

That was close: https://blog.jetbrains.com/kotlin/2018/01/kotlin-1-2-20-is-out/

issue.title: Upgrade to Kotlin 1.2.30

milestone.title: 5.2 M1
milestone.description:
Themes: JUnit BOM, support for Maven Surefire 2.21.0 allowing builds with Java 9 and
Java 10, _argument aggregation_ and _widening primitive conversion_ for arguments in
parameterized tests, external factory methods for `@MethodSource`, as well as various
minor improvements and bug fixes.

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

This PR will introduce Kotlin version 1.2.30 and remove the exclusion of the Kotlin support when running on Java 10.

At the moment, Kotlin 1.2.30 is published as an EAP-47 via their [bintray](https://dl.bintray.com/kotlin/kotlin-eap/org/jetbrains/kotlin/kotlin-compiler/) repository. Therefore this PR is blocked until GA of version 1.2.30.

Closes #1169 

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.

---

### Definition of Done
- [x] Upgrade `kotlinVersion` in `gradle.properties` to `1.2.30`, when it is available
- [x] Remove `https://dl.bintray.com/kotlin/kotlin-eap` repository from `build.gradle`

body:
Kotlin 1.2.30-EAP was just released: https://discuss.kotlinlang.org/t/kotlin-1-2-30-eap/6479

It will fix this issue. See PR #1278 "Upgrade to Kotlin 1.2.30"

Not sure if this is relevant, but sun.rmi might be replaceable by java.rmi in java 10, which might fix those issues for a java 10 build.

It seems as if oracle is kicking sun references out. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/rmi/registry/package-summary.html

Thanks for the heads-up.

The underlying reason here was an out-dated ASM version used by the Kotlin compiler.
